The origin of parasitism is one of the most fundamental questions in biology. The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are thought to have evolved from free-living cnidarians. We report the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two myxozoans, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare these to the genome and transcriptome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister taxon to the more complex group of Nematoda. We also show that myxozoans are among the most reduced animals in terms of genome size and gene content. These results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 70% to meet this demand. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the variability of maize yields will increase dramatically, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially, especially in the major maize-exporting countries. These results highlight the importance of breeding for heat tolerance, and they underscore the urgency of investments in this area.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in natural ecosystems. However, the extent to which species differ in their food-plant preferences is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in food consumption. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify the food-plant preferences of seven species of large African herbivores, and found that the degree of overlap in food-plant preferences was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, species differed in their food-plant preferences, and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These findings suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that the diversity of large herbivores may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses between March 28 and April 4, 2020. The survey asked about the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on business operations and financial health. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is a key determinant of the expected duration of business closures. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, many small businesses plan to seek funding through the CARES Act, but many anticipate problems accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the marine environment. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is much less than expected, and that the majority of it is concentrated in convergence zones of the subtropical gyres. This distribution is mostly due to the selective removal of millimeter-sized fragments of plastic by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size over the last 70 y, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes is a pathological hallmark of multiple system atrophy (MSA), a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is well tolerated in patients with epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes of a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is a key event in the pathogenesis of MSA. In addition, VX-765 was able to limit the progressive toxicity of α-syn aggregation in oligodendrocytes. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues of the body. It is the primary regulator of the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to detect and respond to the presence of specific stimuli. The endothelium is the target of many drugs and is the focus of many diseases. The communication system between the cells of the endothelium is poorly understood. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. This work provides a new perspective on the design of the communication network between cells. It may lead to new insights into the nature of the communication system between endothelial cells and may lead to the development of new therapies for cardiovascular diseases.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health agencies and researchers. We describe the design and operation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We hope that this resource will help to empower researchers and decision makers to track the pandemic and respond effectively.

The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the pore of K+ channels, and it is the site of ion conduction. The selectivity filter is also the site of the activation gate, which is the gatekeeper of the channel. We have identified a key residue for the functional and structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have also demonstrated that the selectivity filter can be used as a switch for the structural collapse of the activation gate. This work provides a structural basis for the functional and structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a structural basis for the structural collapse of the activation gate. This work is expected to provide a structural basis for the design of new types of potassium channel inhibitors.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem of microorganisms that is essential for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential for the microbiome to be manipulated therapeutically is being explored. The gut microbiome is also susceptible to disruption by antibiotics and other factors, and the ability to manipulate the microbiome in a beneficial manner is an area of active research. This study demonstrates that anaerobic fungi, which are a component of the gut microbiome, synthesize natural products that could be used to manipulate the microbiome and potentially treat disease.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that trait anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. The ability to design and fabricate mechanical structures with desired mechanical behaviors is of great importance for the development of various applications. However, the design of such structures is often limited by the availability of materials and the knowledge of the designer. Here, we propose a synthesis method of composite structures with multiple material phases, which are optimally designed to achieve specific target behaviors. The structures are digitally synthesized and then manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The structures are heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design and fabrication of mechanical structures with desired behaviors.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development and the life span of the human body. The hemoglobin system is also a target for the treatment of anemia. Here we show that the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway is involved in the regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. We also show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key element in the regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. We show that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction is a promising strategy for the treatment of cancer.

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers, which are associated with the development of heart failure. Our study shows that the three major classes of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers act on the N terminus of STIM to cause STIM relocalization to junctions and subsequent activation of ORAI, which is required for the promotion of vascular remodeling. Our findings indicate that L-type Ca2+ channel blockers promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study provides a mechanism of L-type Ca2+ channel blocker action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrates that L-type Ca2+ channel blockers promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI.

The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the medical community. This is due to the fact that bacteria are becoming increasingly resistant to the existing antibiotics. Therefore, it is necessary to develop new strategies to combat this problem. In this work, we present a rational design approach to develop new acylide antibiotics. The design strategy is based on the prediction of the solubility, the binding affinity to the ribosome, and the membrane permeability of the compounds. The best candidate was tested in vitro and in vivo, and it was found to be active against resistant pathogens. This work is a step forward in the development of new antibiotics. It is expected that the design strategy presented here will be useful for the development of new acylide antibiotics. This will help to combat the problem of antibiotic resistance.

We introduce a new deep convolutional neural network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is expected to be useful in many other problems in computer vision.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of the effects of environmental change on biological adaptation. The species flock is endemic to Lake Malawi, and the evolution of the group is thought to be driven by the rapid evolution of new species in response to environmental change. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of hydroclimate variability from Lake Malawi, East Africa, which shows that the evolution of the species flock was influenced by the large-scale hydroclimate. The evolution of the species flock is also linked to the evolution of the climate, with periods of extreme drought interrupting the high-amplitude, high-frequency lake level oscillations. These results have important implications for the evolution of species flocks and the role of hydroclimate variability in the origin and diversification of species.

The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has become ubiquitous in the past 50 y. However, the impact of these devices on sleep is unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device for 1 h before bedtime suppresses melatonin, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces the following night’s sleep. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the last 10,000 y. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. However, the origin of the Os in the bolide impact ejecta is unknown. We show that the Os in the bolide impact ejecta is of terrestrial origin.

The role of CTLA-4 in the regulation of the immune response is well established, but the specific contribution of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in the development of a variety of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that the role of CTLA-4 in the regulation of the immune response is not limited to the early stages of the immune response, but also in the development of autoimmunity.

The evolution of beetles is one of the most important events in the history of animal life, but the origin and diversification of this group remain poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of beetles, including the origins of their diet, and show that the evolution of herbivory in beetles was driven by the acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This study reveals a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. It also suggests the hypothesis that APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest part of the Earth. The inner core is thought to have formed by the solidification of molten iron, but the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much easier than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase, and that the body-centered cubic phase is the stable phase at the inner core temperature. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results are important for understanding the origin and evolution of the inner core. They also provide a new perspective for understanding the nucleation of other solids.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less clear. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction severity and craving.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the brain’s processing of it is a central focus of neuroscience. However, the brain’s mechanisms for understanding language are not understood well, and there is no computational framework linking brain and behavior across many datasets and many models. Here, we use the most powerful deep learning models in neuroscience to make novel predictions about the brain’s processing of language. We find that these models predict nearly 100% of the explainable variance in neural responses to sentences, and that model architecture is a major contributor to this predictive power. These results provide computational evidence for the fundamental role of predictive processing in the brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been plagued by instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that the algorithms used to train DL models are not well-conditioned, even though the models are universal approximators. We introduce a new class of algorithms, fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which are stable and converge to the optimal solution. We prove that only a small number of layers are needed to achieve a given accuracy. Our results have implications for the theory of neural networks and for the development of new algorithms for scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a renewed interest in the psychology of exponential growth. In the 1970s, a classic experiment was conducted to study the relationship between the perceived rate of growth and the perceived severity of a threat. The experiment’s critical design flaws were not noticed at the time, but are now widely discussed. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study—undermining an experiment’s methodology while, ironically, still supporting its conclusion.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and is still with us today. It is caused by two related bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which are very similar in genome sequence and have diverged only recently. This study provides a near-complete genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, and shows that the two bacteria have retained many of the same genes, despite their ancient separation. This study also provides a phylogeographic survey of leprosy, which is the most common human mycobacterial infection. The results of this survey show that M. lepromatosis is more prevalent in Mexico than in other countries, and that the two bacteria are still able to cause similar diseases. These findings have implications for the development of vaccines and drugs for leprosy. (Show more)

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in quantum many-body systems is a central topic of current research. However, a complete understanding of the dynamics is still lacking, especially for interacting systems. Here, we show that the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit can be completely understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement with numerical data. Our work provides a new perspective on the dynamics of entanglement and entropy, which is of general interest for isolated quantum systems.

The development of a safe and effective vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 is a critical step in the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic. Here, we describe the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is the only one currently in clinical development. The vaccine is highly attenuated, has a large-scale manufacturing potential, and is protective in a relevant animal model.

The Second Pandemic of plague, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries, was the longest and most devastating of the four pandemics of plague. The vector of plague during this period is unknown, but it is thought to have been a human ectoparasite vector. We present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector and show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in the study of animal cognition. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not well understood. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of brain information-processing capacity. We also show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is associated with the evolution of the number of neurons, which are the basic computational units of the brain.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been the subject of intense investigation, but the results have been mixed. Some studies have shown that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor, while others have shown that it is an oncogene. We have found that TRAP1 is a metabolic regulator, and that it acts as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements that are responsible for many cellular processes. They are dynamic structures that can be assembled and disassembled, and they can also be severed. Severing is a critical process that is required for many cellular processes, such as cell migration. However, the molecular mechanism of severing is not well understood. Here, we show that the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins is able to sever actin filaments. We show that the ADF/cofilin-induced severing is enhanced by the mechanical torque that is generated by the twist of filaments that are held between two anchoring points. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. We propose that this mechanism is generally applicable to other severing proteins. This work provides a molecular understanding of severing, which is a fundamental process in many cellular processes. It also provides a general mechanism for how mechanical torque can enhance protein activity.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in place of glucose in processed foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation of reward-related regions and greater desire for food, which may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we show that the settlement of Madagascar happened in several waves, with a recent admixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations. We also show that the settlement of Madagascar was not homogeneous, and that the genetic structure is influenced by geography. These results are important for understanding the history of Madagascar, and for the development of genomic tools to study the human population in the Indian Ocean.

We show that the emotions of others can influence our own emotions, even when we are not interacting with the person who is expressing the emotion. This is a major advance in our understanding of the mechanisms of emotion, and suggests that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The ribosome is the central enzyme of protein synthesis, and the mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are modified in many ways. We show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can have a profound effect on the rate of protein synthesis. Our work suggests that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can have a profound effect on the rate of protein synthesis.

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to the inclusion of a range of factors that may be associated with the outcomes, such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, or with the measurement of worthwhile ratings. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of aquatic life has been a major driver of the diversification of mammals. We use a model of the energetics of feeding and thermoregulation to show that the evolution of aquatic life is driving mammals toward a size attractor of ∼500 kg. This size attractor is consistent with the existence of a minimum size and a maximum size that are both constrained by the energetics of feeding and thermoregulation.

The common cold is the most common viral infection worldwide, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been the subject of much debate, and the reasons for the preference of rhinovirus for the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity are not well understood. We show that the mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature, and that this preference is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of rhinovirus vaccines and antiviral therapies. (Show more)

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in their surroundings. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to detect the presence of surfaces, and that this signal is used to regulate the expression of a large number of genes, including virulence factors. This is the first demonstration of a mechanochemical model for sensing surfaces by bacteria.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We show that the concentrations of pesticides in surface water are much higher than previously thought, and that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the human population, and the virus has spread to many animal species. The potential for the virus to persist in wildlife populations and the impact on the health of both humans and animals is unknown. We report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living and captive white-tailed deer, and the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in deer during the peak of the human pandemic. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the food system. This paper examines the problems and the opportunities for the hydropower industry to move toward sustainable practices. We show that the benefits of hydropower are overestimated and the costs underestimated. We also show that the industry needs to move toward sustainable practices and that there are innovative solutions that can move the industry toward sustainable practices.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide public health crisis. The disease is thought to be driven by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, but the earliest events in the disease process are poorly understood. We show that soluble and oligomeric Aβ are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain, and that they are responsible for the activation of neurons and the release of cytokines, which are critical for the initiation of the AD immune response. These findings have implications for the development of novel AD therapeutics, as well as for the understanding of the immune response in other neurodegenerative diseases.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still unknown. We present a detailed faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant during the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. This is the earliest known evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens in the world.

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of proteins at the single-molecule level. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein of 370 residues that is known to fold through distinct intermediates. We find that the folding of the protein is much more complex than previously thought.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not well understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme RppH, which is inactivated by Np4, is the predominant enzyme responsible for the deprotection of Np4-capped RNAs. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression induced by sepsis are not fully understood, but it is clear that arginine deprivation is a key factor. We show that arginine deprivation is also a key factor in the immunosuppression induced by sepsis, and that increasing arginine availability can restore T cell function and proliferation. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis reveals that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results highlight the importance of the human footprint on the global biomass of the biosphere.

We present a model of self-organized criticality (SOC) in which the dynamics is continuous in time and space. This is in contrast to all known models of SOC, which are discrete in time and space. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this paper is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects, impurities, and external stimuli. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This work provides a new route to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond, and it will have a significant impact on the development of diamond-based devices.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great importance for the development of new drugs. The study of the antifungal activity of peptides is of great importance for the development of new fungicides.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the life history of sperm is intimately linked to the female reproductive tract. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm is altered after being transferred to the female reproductive tract, and we identify female-derived proteins that associate with sperm. These proteins are enriched for metabolic processes, suggesting that they support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the life history of Drosophila sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. (Show more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a key component of the blood clotting system. It binds to the platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) and, in the presence of factor VIII, is responsible for the formation of a stable complex that is required for blood clotting. We show that force can be used to switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for the activation of VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a common disorder of blood clotting.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the role of viruses in human health has been much less studied, and the lack of a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses has hindered the study of this important component of the microbiome. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, and shows that viruses are associated with many diseases. This database will be a valuable resource for the scientific community.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the interaction process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL to investigate the ACI. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This work will contribute to the understanding of the role of aerosols in the climate system. It will also provide a new capability for the climate community to investigate the ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for decades. The current estimate of 15 °C is based on the isotopic composition of marine cherts. However, this estimate is subject to question due to uncertainties regarding the isotopic compositions of the oceans, the possibility of isotopic resetting, and the depositional environments. We here present a method for determining the temperature of Earth’s surface based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations.

Ion channels are the main ion conduits in the cell and are regulated by their pore gates. The pore gate of the K+ channel, the BK channel, is unique in that it lacks a classic bundle-crossing activation gate. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is also unique in that it is state dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 1 million deaths occurring each year. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC), the target of the disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a key adhesin, 175, to bind to the glycophorin A receptor on the RBC surface. We show that this interaction leads to a change in the physical properties of the RBC, which is required for invasion. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat this disease. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, without phonon instability, through strain engineering. This opens up opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies.

The impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection is controversial. In this study, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases the severity of influenza virus infection. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the role of humidity in the severity of influenza virus infection. They also suggest that the impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection may depend on the host defense and repair capacity of the host. These findings may help to develop strategies to mitigate the severity of influenza virus infection. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in a left-corner fashion, starting with the simplest elements and gradually adding more complex ones. However, there is no direct evidence for this hypothesis. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the construction of syntactic structures increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, providing evidence for a merge mechanism that applies to the brain’s representation of language. Our results suggest that the brain uses a bottom-up or left-corner parser to build syntactic structures. They also provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development, and its regulation is important for the proper functioning of the body. We show that the two forms of Axin, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant, are regulated differently, and that this difference is important for the proper functioning of the pathway. This is an example of the importance of subtle differences in gene regulation for the proper functioning of the body.

The brain is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the function of any one part without considering the function of the entire system. This study provides a comprehensive characterization of a brain circuit that may contribute to the development of obesity.

The ability of plants to fix nitrogen (N2) from the atmosphere is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle and is essential for the growth of all terrestrial plants. However, the natural symbiosis between plants and the nitrogen-fixing bacteria is inefficient, and the symbiosis is often lost during crop evolution. We have developed a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This technology has the potential to improve the efficiency of N2 fixation in agriculture, which is a key component of sustainable food production.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. The estimated effects are largest in communities facing the largest threats. Data from monitoring records and community surveys provide evidence about how the program may affect forest outcomes. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The spider is a model organism for studying the evolution of animal senses, and in particular, hearing. Here, we show that the spider’s hearing is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We show that the climate and health impacts of air pollution are strongly coupled, and that removing air pollution is a win for both. We also show that the climate and health impacts of greenhouse gases are strongly coupled, and that removing greenhouse gases is a win for both.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death, and the need for vaccines remains urgent. We report the design, synthesis, and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 receptor-binding domain (RBD) variant that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits a strong immune response. This variant is expected to be more manufacturable, more immunogenic, and more protective than the Wuhan-Hu-1 RBD used in current vaccines.

The study of the development of the neural crest, a population of cells that gives rise to a large number of tissues and organs, is of great interest for the understanding of the origin of the human body plan. In this study, we show that the zebrafish homolog of the human ALK receptor, DrLtk, is a direct target of the ALKAL proteins, which are implicated in the development of neuroblastoma, a pediatric cancer. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALKALs in the development of the neural crest and open the way for the study of the role of ALKALs in human cancer.

The emergence of plague, the most devastating infectious disease in human history, is a mystery that has puzzled scientists for centuries. We present the genomes of 17 plague strains from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a unique window into the early evolution of plague and its relationship to its host, the flea. Our results suggest that plague was not a single, local pathogen, but rather a highly mobile disease that spread across Eurasia and beyond. This study provides a new perspective on the early history of plague and its relationship to its host, the flea.

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in the 2016 and 2020 presidential elections. We find that men’s and women’s endorsement of HM predicted support for Donald Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, HM predicted evaluations of Trump, over and above social and prejudiced attitudes, and these effects held when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The management of agricultural lands has been a major driver of the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has led to the release of 1.5 Pg C of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) to the atmosphere. This study shows that the management of grasslands can be a powerful tool for sequestering carbon in the soil. The results of this study have implications for the management of agricultural lands worldwide.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses to humans and the development of strategies to mitigate this risk. We developed a framework to identify risk factors for spillover and a web tool to rank the risk of 887 wildlife viruses. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of the spillover potential of these viruses can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for the services they provide in the form of pollination. The color of nectar is an important cue for pollinators, and the evolution of colorful nectar is a well-known phenomenon in nature. However, the mechanism by which colorful nectar is produced is not well understood. Here, we identify a new class of colorful nectar pigments, which are produced by a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a mechanism by which colorful nectar is produced, and show that this mechanism is convergent in two different species. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of colorful nectar, and the mechanisms by which this trait is produced. This work also provides a new class of colorful pigments for use in the development of new pigments for industrial and medical applications. (Show more)

We present a study of the genetic ancestry of women from the Early Medieval period in Europe. We show that women’s genomes are highly heterogeneous, and that some of this heterogeneity is due to genetic ancestry that is not found in modern Europeans. We also show that some of these women had skull deformations, which may have been due to the practice of cranial deformation in the region. We further show that some of these women had genetic ancestry that is not found in modern Europeans, and that this genetic ancestry is not due to migration from outside Europe. Finally, we show that many alleles associated with positive selection are already at modern-like frequencies in European populations. These findings have important implications for our understanding of the genetic history of Europe, and the role of women in shaping the genetic landscape of the continent.

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5 are investigated. The results show that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 are opposite to those of MERS-CoV, which is the causative agent of Middle East respiratory syndrome. These results suggest that the spike protein of MERS-CoV has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. This study provides insights into the evolution of bat coronaviruses and the mechanism of MERS-CoV transmission to humans. It also suggests that bat coronaviruses may pose a threat to human health. (Show more)

The rapid identification of pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to the early detection and response to emerging and reemerging diseases. We show that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a feasible and cost-effective approach to pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. We demonstrate the ability to detect a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a single test, and to identify the most important pathogens responsible for undifferentiated febrile illness. This approach can be used to rapidly identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens, and to deploy rapid public health response.

The human genome is replicated in a process that is highly similar to the process used by bacteria to replicate their DNA. However, the human genome is much larger and, as a result, the process is much slower. The process of replication is also much more complex as it involves the synthesis of two strands of DNA, one of which is synthesized in the 3′ to 5′ direction, and the other in the 5′ to 3′ direction. This process is known as lagging strand synthesis. The process of lagging strand synthesis is much more complex than the process used by bacteria and requires the use of many different proteins. One of the proteins involved in lagging strand synthesis is DNA polymerase δ. In this study, we show that the human DNA polymerase δ protein is not as stable as the DNA polymerase δ protein from S. cerevisiae. This difference in stability has important implications for the process of lagging strand synthesis in humans.

The origin of life is one of the most important questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, the evolution of life has been achieved by the stepwise addition of proteins. Here, we show that the evolution of life can be achieved by the stepwise addition of RNA molecules.

We use computer vision to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods over time. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are related to the economic and demographic characteristics of their residents. Specifically, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements, neighborhoods with better initial appearances are more likely to experience larger improvements, and neighborhoods that are physically close to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvements. These findings provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab is evaluated. The results show that tocilizumab is effective in the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients, and may be a potential treatment for COVID-19.

The role of natural products in the regulation of microbial interactions is well established in bacteria, but less so in fungi. Here we report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. The existence of this class of fungal natural products suggests that the role of natural products in the regulation of microbial interactions is not limited to bacteria.

The presence of tridymite, a high-temperature polymorph of silica, in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, and the amorphous silica is a diagenetic product. The tridymite and other crystalline minerals are detrital, and the amorphous silica is a product of multiple aqueous infiltrations. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery.

The impact of late-spring frosts on the performance of plants and animals is a major concern for agriculture, forestry, and wildlife. We show that the geographic distribution of late-spring frosts is changing, and that this change is not uniform across the Northern Hemisphere. Our results provide a framework for understanding the impact of late-spring frosts and the vulnerability of forests to climate change.

Th17 cells are a recently discovered subset of CD4+ T cells that are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of these cells are not well understood. We show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. We have developed a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study the disease and test potential therapies. This will help us to understand the disease and identify new targets for therapy.

The gut microbiota of ticks is a complex community of bacteria, fungi, and viruses that is essential for the survival of the tick and the pathogen it harbors. We now show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitates the colonization of the pathogen in the tick. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to more effectively colonize its vector. This knowledge may be useful in the development of strategies to control the spread of vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the evolution of birds. The study of the evolution of the avian tail is important for understanding the origin of flight and the evolution of the modern avian body plan. However, the study of the evolution of the avian tail is hindered by the lack of fossils. Here, we describe a basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, the pygostylians, and show that this group is an important link in the evolution of the avian tail.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere is increasing, and that this increase is contributing to the warming of the climate. This is a new finding, and it is important because it shows that the water vapor feedback is not the only feedback that is contributing to the overall climate sensitivity.

The color of animals is an important component of their communication with the environment. In this study, we describe a mechanism that allows animals to control the color of their bodies, and provide evidence of the evolution of this mechanism multiple times in the vertebrate lineage.

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, and is associated with the emergence of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. We show that hypoxia induces expression of a protein, AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modifications on mRNA. ALKBH5 expression is increased in breast cancer, and is associated with the emergence of cancer stem cells. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia, and is required for the enrichment of cancer stem cells in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world, and the first pocket Bible was a major innovation in the history of the book. The source of the parchment used to make these Bibles has been a long-standing controversy. We have developed a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. Our results show that the source of the parchment was not the use of abortive or newborn animals, but rather the use of hides of maturing animals of several species. This suggests that the production of these Bibles was not limited by the availability of animals, but rather by the ability to produce parchment of the desired fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction is the most severe extinction in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is unknown, but the timing, duration, and rate of recovery are well constrained. The age model for the extinction is based on U-Pb zircon dates from five volcanic ash beds. The age model is refined by the dates, which define the timing of the extinction and recovery. The dates also provide a precise age for the onset of the carbon cycle reorganization, which is a key event in the extinction. The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. It is essential to maintain the homeostasis of the intestinal epithelium to prevent the invasion of pathogens and the entry of toxic substances into the body. However, the intestinal epithelium is also the first line of defense against the invasion of immune cells, which can cause intestinal inflammation. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our findings provide a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the target of the majority of neutralizing antibodies and is the primary target of the COVID-19 vaccine. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with the receptor ACE2, and we have compared the structure of the spike in complex with the wild-type receptor to the structure of the spike in complex with the mutant receptor. We find that the mutant spike is more flexible and can adopt a range of more open conformations.

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate the impact of the pandemic on life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest in other fields, such as physics, biology, and engineering. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we discover that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. Our results are of great interest for the chemical community, and they can be used to predict and explain the behavior of matter under pressure. They can also be used in other fields, such as physics, biology, and engineering.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, but the effects on the global carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of changes in global fire activity. This has the potential to reduce the rate of warming, although the magnitude of the effect depends on the strength of climate–carbon cycle feedbacks. Our results highlight the importance of human activities in shaping the future of fire and the carbon cycle.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which the host controls the activity of the symbionts are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to control the activity of the symbionts in a specific mutualism. We also show that the catabolism of this glycan is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. These results suggest that the provision of a single glycan may be a general mechanism used by animals to control the activity of their symbionts. This may be particularly important for the control of the activity of luminescent symbionts, which are often used as bioluminescent markers in biomedical research. This study provides a new perspective on the control of symbiosis. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but the patterns they encode are difficult to identify. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as sequences of topics. We use this method to identify the topics that are encoded in the narratives of the National Violent Death Reporting System, a database of violent death incidents. We find that the narratives encode many topics that are not captured by the structured variables of the database. We also find that the topics are gendered, and that the gendered nature of the topics is related to the gender of the victim. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains, and it can be extended to other types of data. We believe that it will be useful to many researchers.

The Black Death, the deadliest epidemic in human history, is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We show that the introduction of plague into Europe was not a one-off event, but rather repeated over the course of four centuries. Our results suggest that the introduction of plague into Europe was the result of a series of introductions, each of which was followed by a delay of 15 ± 1 y before the disease became established in the rodent reservoir.

The sea-star wasting disease (SSWD) is one of the most devastating diseases affecting marine animals. The disease is caused by a virus that has spread rapidly through the population of asteroids, leading to the loss of more than 90% of the population. We show that the virus is transmitted by the starfish itself, and that the disease can be prevented by the injection of the virus. This is the first time that a virus has been shown to be transmitted by the starfish itself, and to be the cause of the disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease with a poor prognosis. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. We show that a monoclonal antibody targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is effective in suppressing the growth of AML cells in xenograft models. This antibody is capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of this approach in other diseases.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history and a unique genetic structure. We present a high-resolution view of the genetic structure of the Malagasy population, which is a key step to understand the history of Madagascar.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (denoted GlpD) and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, providing information on the status of crops that is critical for the management of agricultural production. However, the information provided by crop experts is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily integrated into quantitative models. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is conducted by the US Department of Agriculture, is a rich source of information that can be used to build quantitative models of crop status. We show that the CPC data can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that can be used to build quantitative models of crop status. We also show that the CPC data can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Language is a highly complex system that is difficult to understand from a mechanistic perspective. Here we propose a model of language processing that is based on the dynamics of single neurons. We show that the dynamics of single neurons can support memory for information about the structure of language over a range of timescales. This memory is not based on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity. Instead, it is based on the dynamics of conductances that control the firing rate of neurons. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The response of soil respiration to experimental warming is a key indicator of the potential for climate change to alter the global carbon cycle. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, leading to conflicting results. Here, we present the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a powerful tool to study the origin and evolution of life. However, the evolutionary history of the genome is often obscured by the presence of functional genes. We present a model of the evolutionary trajectory of the genome during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on the genome, which is reflected in the evolutionary rates and the structure of the genome. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on the genome in a stepwise manner.

The impact of anthropogenic climate change on the probability of extreme droughts in South Africa has not been quantified. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in the past and future decades. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in South Africa to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for the development of adaptation strategies.
