The discovery of quasicrystals in the 1980s was a major breakthrough in the field of materials science. However, the conditions under which they are formed are still not fully understood. This work shows that quasicrystals can be formed under conditions that are not only more common in nature but also existed in the world before the birth of Christ.

Photosynthesis is the primary source of chemical energy on Earth. The capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy is mediated by the photosynthetic pigments, chlorophyll and bacteriochlorophyll. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the characteristic feature of the chlorophyll and bacteriochlorophyll pigments, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one of which is a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, the other a diiron protein. This work reveals the evolution of the diiron enzyme, and the discovery of a protein that is a subunit of the enzyme. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the diiron enzyme, and the biosynthesis of the chlorophyll and bacteriochlorophyll pigments. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is also a major feature in multiple sclerosis (MS), the most common chronic inflammatory demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms of neuroinflammation in MS are not well understood. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was phase specific, and the role of neuroinflammation was dependent on the cell type of the glial cells. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation.

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a genetic basis, and the identification of the causal genes is challenging. We used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and may facilitate the development of new treatments. (Show more)

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of Ca2+ signaling in the immune system, and is also involved in a variety of other cellular processes. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein, ORAI1, or in the Ca2+ sensor, STIM1, result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, and in the pore-forming protein, ORAI1, that result in a Stormorken syndrome of bleeding diathesis, thrombocytopenia, miosis, and tubular aggregate myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spreading of aggregates in the Drosophila brain in a model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may help to identify new therapeutic targets. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified a protein, Myotis pilosus toxin (MTX), that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of bats and demonstrated that MTX is a potent immunomodulator that inhibits the antiviral immune response and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-leukotriene-A4 hydrolase. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the emergence of zoonotic viruses and the development of novel antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one of the most common causes of death worldwide. The underlying mechanisms are complex, but one of the most important is the ability of cancer cells to meet their growing metabolic demands. This study identifies a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and a potential therapeutic target.

The presence of coaggregating proteins in the inclusions of motor neurons in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) has been a long-standing observation. However, the mechanisms that lead to the formation of these inclusions are not well understood. Here, we show that the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS is not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of the three proteins that are mutated in ALS, but rather that the coaggregating proteins are themselves supersaturated in motor neurons. These results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS is a consequence of a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons, and thus may be a common mechanism in the pathogenesis of ALS. This may also be a common mechanism in other neurodegenerative disorders. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The study of the early evolution of angiosperms is hampered by the lack of well-preserved material. Montsechia is a plant that was first described more than 100 y ago, but its study has been hampered by the lack of well-preserved material. Now, based upon the study of more than 1,000 specimens, the morphology and anatomy of Montsechia are presented. The plant is an aquatic angiosperm that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is Barremian in age, raising questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses. Lower Cretaceous aquatic angiosperms, such as Archaefructus and Montsechia, open the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages. (Show more)

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in the field of virology, but the evolution of DNA viruses in particular is poorly understood. We present the first ancient DNA sequences of human parvovirus B19 (B19V), which is associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

The rate of sea level rise is one of the most visible and contentious aspects of climate change. This study provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is the longest period of time for which we have a consistent record of satellite altimeter measurements. The results are in agreement with the IPCC 5th Assessment Report (AR5) model projections.

Pain is a major public health problem, but the causes of the increase in pain are not well understood. We show that the increase in pain is not due to the aging of the population, but rather to the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The structure of the enzyme active site is a key determinant of the reaction pathway and the outcome of the reaction. However, the structure of the transition state, the species that is ultimately reached, and the species that is formed after the reaction is complete are also important. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the reaction of the enzyme active site with a substrate analog, and we use this information to understand the reaction pathway and the outcome. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the enzyme active site, and how this information can be used to understand the reaction pathway and the outcome. This work also highlights the importance of the active site as a chemical reactor, and the role that the active site plays in the catalysis of the protein. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment, and the disease has a high case fatality rate. We show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is approved for use in other diseases, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS, and may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which the host controls the activity of the symbionts are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to control the activity of the symbionts in a specific mutualism. We also show that the catabolism of this glycan is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. These results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general mechanism for the control of the activities of symbionts in animal-microbe interactions. This may be the case for other glycans, as well as for other nutrients, and may be a mechanism used by other animals to control the activities of their symbionts.

This research shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships can be improved, and suspension rates reduced, through the development of an empathic mindset about discipline. This is a scalable intervention, which can be implemented in schools and classrooms around the world.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis are still poorly understood. In this work, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on the fidelity of transcription. We found that the transcription fidelity is strongly dependent on the location of the alkylation. The results from this work provide important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis. This work also provides a better understanding of the impact of DNA alkylation on the fidelity of transcription, which is important for the development of cancer therapy.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. To better understand the role of the spike (S) glycoproteins in MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the sequential proteolysis required for virus entry. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental problems. The food choices of the majority of the population have a large impact on the environment, and so there is a strong case for increasing the proportion of plant-based meals in catering outlets. However, this is difficult to achieve because people are not aware of the environmental benefits of plant-based diets, and because the food industry is resistant to change. We show that it is possible to increase the proportion of plant-based meals offered in a catering outlet by 60% without a significant impact on overall sales. This is a simple and effective way to make a major contribution to environmental sustainability.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. We have developed a method to quantitatively measure the surface proteome, and have applied it to characterize the surfaceome of a panel of six oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is largely unknown. Here, we report the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, potentially mediating unique immune suppression and evasion activities. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the disease caused by SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major risk factor for cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not well understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1. This leads to an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1), which in turn leads to an increase in water influx into the brain and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular understanding of the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. They also provide a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema. This study may also have implications for the understanding of the development of cerebral edema in other conditions, such as brain trauma. (Show more)

We live in an age of big data. This is both a blessing and a curse. On the one hand, the amount of data available to us is unprecedented. On the other hand, the tools for analyzing this data are also unprecedented. This article describes a new way of analyzing data that is appropriate for this age.

The development of vascular networks is a critical step in the regeneration of damaged organs. However, the generation of vascular networks is difficult to achieve in vitro and in vivo. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can induce the formation of vascular networks in vitro and in vivo. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of vascular networks and may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders.

We have identified a family of ligand proteins for the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We have shown that these ligands are essential for the development of the zebrafish iridophores, which are a type of photoreceptor. This is the first demonstration of a physiological role for augmentor ligands and Ltk.

The role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity has been well established. However, its function in β-cell is still unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of seasonal epidemics and occasional pandemics. The packaging of their genome is a key step in the assembly of virions, but the molecular details of this process are still unknown. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments, which is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is sequence specific and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging and could help in the development of antiviral strategies.

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherogenic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the regulation of vascular homeostasis and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that YAP/TAZ is activated by the disturbed flow and promotes the proatherogenic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. In addition, inhibition of YAP/TAZ translation is sufficient to reduce the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. These findings provide insights into the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the regulation of vascular homeostasis and the development of atherosclerotic lesions. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States. This has led to increased economic and ecological costs of wildfire, as well as increased risk to human life and property. This paper provides a quantitative assessment of the role of humans in increasing wildfire activity in the United States.

We use computer vision to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods over time. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements, and neighborhoods that are physically close to other attractive neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvements. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel as a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease and the factors that determine the severity of the disease are not well understood. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir, which blocks viral replication, can be effective in reducing the peak viral load and shortening the time to undetectable viral load. The results presented here can help in the development of effective antiviral therapies for the treatment of ZIKV infection. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including global warming. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is one of the most severe consequences of this breakdown, leading to the death of the coral host. We show that the metabolic and molecular responses of the coral host to heat stress are driven by altered nutrient cycling, which in turn is a consequence of the host’s energy status. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a warming world.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier between the host and the environment. In the presence of tumors, the intestinal epithelium becomes leaky, leading to the loss of homeostasis between the host and the microbiome. We show that the microbiome can trigger a regenerative response in the intestinal epithelium, which in turn can stimulate tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides insights into the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain intestinal barrier function. These findings may have implications for the development of new therapies for cancer and inflammatory bowel disease.

Chemotherapy is an important component of the treatment of breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond to treatment. We show that the expression of the orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this expression correlates with the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft mice. Furthermore, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with a humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab and chemotherapy is more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of Antarctic ice sheet melting is one of the most important questions in the history of the Southern Hemisphere climate system. We show that the start of accelerated Antarctic ice sheet melting was coincident with a volcanic eruption, and that the eruption was associated with stratospheric ozone depletion.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and the sustainability of fisheries. We find that inland fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our analysis also reveals that fishing pressure is most intense in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors, highlighting the need for sustainable management of inland fisheries. Our data can be used to inform the design of effective conservation and management strategies for freshwater fisheries.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the proposed material are responsible for the high capacity and the safe operation of the full cell. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of aqueous batteries.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery has implications for the study of regeneration in the adult nervous system, as well as for the development of regenerative therapies.

The process of meiosis is essential for the production of genetically diverse gametes, but the rate of recombination between homologous chromosomes is a major determinant of the speed of the process. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we show that the pattern of recombination is similar to that in yeast and in mice. This suggests that the process of initiation of recombination is conserved in eukaryotes, and that the polarity of recombination in genes is a more recent development.

The brain is organized in networks of functionally related brain regions. The identification of these networks is a key step in understanding the functional architecture of the brain. Here, we show that the metabolic organization of the brain can be used to identify resting state networks, and that this approach can be used to monitor the progression of Parkinson’s disease. This approach can be extended to the study of other neurodegenerative diseases, and to the study of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA, and is essential for the stability and translation of mRNA. We have discovered a second 5′ modification in yeast, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. The NAD+ cap is not found on pre-mRNAs, and is only found on transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. This suggests that the NAD+ cap may have a role in regulating the translation of specific subsets of mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. The mechanisms of metabolic memory are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

This study provides a mechanism for the role of FSIP1 in the sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer cells to chemotherapy. This study also provides a potential target for the development of new therapies for triple-negative breast cancer.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which may be related to the development of psychological symptoms. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects, suggesting that the gut microbiota may be a target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the contribution of these compounds to the overall flavor of tomato fruit is not well understood. We have identified a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of these compounds, and will be a valuable resource for the tomato breeding community.

We show that the impacts of global warming on the functioning of ecosystems are exacerbated by biodiversity loss. This is because the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is altered by temperature, and the magnitude of this change depends on the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning, and the need for a more holistic approach to the management of our changing environment.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to represent different aspects of the environment. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of MEC neurons in freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to represent the local environment, are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells, which are thought to represent the global environment. These findings have implications for understanding the organization of the MEC and its role in navigation.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal, FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT), is required for flowering of the host and the parasite in a host–parasite interaction. This study illustrates the importance of FTs in interplant communication and the role of FTs in the regulation of flowering.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigro system, which project to the striatum to form the classic nigrostriatal pathway, are part of a much larger system that includes the striosome–dendron bouquets. These formations, here termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are composed of striosomal cell bodies, their associated striosomal fibers, and the dopamine-containing dendrites that they innervate. We suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We are all familiar with the feeling of “clicking” with someone. But how do we know when two people are “clicking”? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed with which we respond to others is a robust predictor of how connected we feel to them. We also show that this signal is used by third-party listeners to assess the quality of the connection between two people. This finding has implications for our understanding of the social world, as well as for the design of technologies that support social connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of the heart rate. The SAN is a highly coordinated system that is sensitive to changes in the environment. In this study, we show that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the SAN.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based pest management strategies. (Show more)

The lipidome of cells is a complex mixture of many different lipids, which are involved in many cellular processes. The lipidome of cells is affected by many factors, including the cellular state, the cell type, and the treatment. Here we show that the cellular lipidome is also affected by the activity of a specific enzyme, alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in ether lipid metabolism.

Language is a highly complex system that involves the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to use a variety of mechanisms to support this process, but the neurobiological basis of memory in language is poorly understood. Here we propose a mechanism that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can support the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. This is due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important for the internalization and gene silencing efficiencies. This work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization. This work also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants for both basic and applied research.

The world’s largest lakes are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication, which can reduce water quality and harm the ecosystem services they provide. We show that the nutrient loads delivered to the coast are dominated by a small number of large tributaries, but that the nutrient composition of these loads is different from that of the rest of the watershed. Small tributaries are more likely to deliver nutrients in dissolved forms, which are more bioavailable to algae, and are more likely to be trapped in the nearshore zone. Our findings highlight the importance of small watersheds in coastal eutrophication, and the need to consider them in future management efforts.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a fluctuating environment. We find that the network can exhibit a bias toward states that extremize the environmental forcing. This bias is due to the fact that the network is composed of a large number of distinct chemical reactions, each of which is catalytically active only in a narrow range of chemical concentrations.

The effects of antibodies against the N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptor on the brain are poorly understood. Here we show that these antibodies can change the dynamics of the brain, and that this can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We also show that the effects of the antibodies can be explained by changes in the dynamics of the brain, and that these changes are consistent with the observed EEG abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the effects of antibodies on the brain, and may help to explain the diversity of effects observed in patients with this disorder.

The history of carbon perturbation events is important for understanding the Earth system’s response to abrupt warming. However, most studies have focused on short-term warming events superimposed on longer-term greenhouse climate states. Here, we present an integrated proxy and modeling approach to investigate an abrupt carbon perturbation and global warming event that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. These results have implications for the history of carbon perturbation events and the Earth system’s response to abrupt warming.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. Despite this, the impact of RSPO certification on deforestation has not been evaluated. We show that RSPO certification is associated with a reduction in deforestation, but that this effect is limited to areas that are already deforested. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having a large impact on deforestation, and that the scheme is not yet having a large impact on forest loss.

The exocyst complex is a large protein complex that is essential for the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the functioning of all kingdoms of life. The exocyst complex is a promising target for the development of drugs to treat diseases such as diabetes and cancer. However, the development of drugs is limited by the lack of a suitable tool to study the exocyst complex. We discovered a small molecule that binds to the exocyst complex and inhibits exocytosis. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocyst complex and the development of drugs to treat diseases. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the evolution of sex determination is a major topic of study. In this work, we investigate the effects of a single genetic locus on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics in a species with polygenic sex determination. We find that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination may be a general feature of sex determination, and that the maintenance of modularity may be a key feature of sex determination in general.

The retina is a unique organ in that it is challenged by two distinct classes of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are generated by photoreceptors and RPE, respectively. The photoreceptor-generated ROS are quenched by the RPE, but the RPE is challenged by the RPE-generated ROS, which are not quenched. We show that the levels of iron in the retina impact the balance between the photoreceptor and RPE-generated ROS.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understand the functioning of the food web. However, the evolution of predator specialization is often considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of predator specialization is not a dead end, but rather a process that has led to the diversification of the feeding strategies of the animal kingdom.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. The study of the human hand is complicated by the fact that it is the most complex part of the body, and the fossil record is sparse and fragmentary. We present the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one of the most common genetic aberrations is the loss of function of the one-carbon pool donor, serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it is effective in inhibiting colon cancer cell growth in vitro and in vivo. We also show that the one-carbon donor, formate, is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We propose that defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This work provides a new target for cancer therapy, and a potential mechanism for the differential sensitivity of B-cell lines and lymphomas to SHMT inhibition. This work also provides a new scaffold for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT. (Show more)

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and biodiversity security. This study shows that natural landscapes, such as forests, can contribute to meeting these goals. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

The mechanization of agriculture has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, allowing for the expansion of food production and the reduction of hunger. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods, the largest animals that walked Earth, would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This study highlights the importance of considering the effects of modern farm machinery on soil ecology and the need for more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. This will allow for the continued expansion of food production while minimizing the risks of subsoil compaction.
